OK we've done Oscar vs Crawford time for Tszyu vs him

Amateur record

Tszyu 259-11 (I've also seen it listed as 260-10)

Crawford's 70-12

So Crawford incurred more loses in 82 fights than Tszyu did in 270 even though he fought at a much lower level than Tszyu

And obviously Tszyu's amateur accomplishments>>>Crawford's by a country mile

Tszyu's opponent's win/loss ratio

Tszyu 1064-130 loses

Crawford 514-205

Number of world champions fought

Tszyu 15 (13-2)

Crawford 4 (4-0)

Number of world title fights

Tszyu 18

Crawford 10

Number of times fought on the road

Tszyu 15 including unifying twice in his opponent's country and winning his first world title in his opponent's country too. So he won all his world titles in his opponent's country and defended his titles many times on the road and in his opponent's country

Crawford 1 for his first world title fight

Obviously winning on the road or in your opponent's home country is more difficult for a number of different reasons and more impressive than beating them in your backyard/country where often everything is stacked in your favour and against them. Beating Zab Judah or Sharmba Mitchell in their country>>>beating them in Australia or Russia. Winning away>>winning at home.

Crawford has fought outside of his country once, whereas Tszyu did it 15 times, 15 fights on the road out of 33 fights.

No-one has addressed the elephant in the room - Tszyu's losses.

Both came when he was underdone in terms of fights leading into the fateful days (or nights as the case may have been).

As an obvious statement, both losses were extremely hard fought wars of attrition. Saying "Tszyu quit" in the Hatton fight ignores the fact his corner pulled him out after receiving a non-response to the question of was he okay to continue. He was obviously gone and should not have continued. It's debatable whether he even understood what he was being asked - but I digress.

There were a number of issues that contributed to the Vince Phillips loss, the two most important being:

1. Phillips, a decent fighter with good punching power, fought a great fight, and

2. Tszyu's lack of competitive action leading into the fight meant he was underdone going in and ultimately not capable of withstanding such an unexpectedly strong challenge.

The seeds for the Vince Phillips loss were sewn when Tszyu's management chose Leonardo Mas as an opponent in his previous fight instead of Charles Murray (a decent American who would have given Tszyu rounds). Mas was hopeless, couldn't stay upright and was stopped easily in the first. The ref ruled technical draw for a late punch which at the time, stained Tszyu's perfect record. Tszyu spent much of the lead-up to the Phillips fight upset about that as well as losing a court case to his former promoter. While they were distractions out of the ring I think the fact Tszyu didn't get any meaningful work against Mas (following on from a couple of one-sided fights in Australia the previous year) left him vulnerable in his next fight. Tszyu's management should have chosen Charles Murray who would not have taken a dive in the first round. They were offered both potential opponents & chose Mas presumably believing he was an easier fight for the same money. They were right about that but I reckon it cost them next fight.

There were lots of other reasons given for the Vince Phillips loss but I think it was as simple as Phillips being fight hardened coming in (he lost a tough 10-rounder not long before) & Kostya Tszyu being underdone (as a consequence of opponent choices made by his own management).

The moral of the story is it's a fine line in boxing & timing is everything.

Tszyu had long stretches of inactivity leading into the Hatton fight & was underdone for that one as well. Probably shouldn't have been fighting at that weight at that time either. He looked like a corpse at the weigh-in. In saying that, he looked terrific against Sharmba Mitchell in his previous fight (despite also looking like a corpse at the weigh-in) but that one didn't last very long either.

When you find yourself in a tough war of attrition, you need some tough hard rounds behind you in order to prevail at the back end of the fight.

Tszyu didn't have them going into either the Vince Phillips or Ricky Hatton fights.
